---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
I wanted to define
```
def FractionalOperation (D : Type*) (m k : ℕ) : Type :=
  (Fin m → D) → (Fin k → D)
```
but it Lean doesn't let me use `Type*` here.
@eric-wieser
Any idea why?
Does it work if you make the return type `Type*`?

> Does it work if you make the return type `Type*`?

No,

> > Does it work if you make the return type `Type*`?
> 
> No,

But it makes the rest work with `Type*` despite of `Type _` in the `FractionalOperation` definition!

> I wanted to define
> 
> ```
> def FractionalOperation (D : Type*) (m k : ℕ) : Type :=
>   (Fin m → D) → (Fin k → D)
> ```
> 
> but it Lean doesn't let me use `Type*` here. @eric-wieser Any idea why?

Please note the new version with  `Type*` as output.
I'll attempt to refactor it.
Is it better now? What else would you @fpvandoorn suggest the API to provide?

> 
> Similarly, `Function.AdmitsFractional` should probably quantify over `Matrix (Fin n) (Fin m) D`.
> 
> Note: you need to import `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Notation` to do this

I was asking about using `Matrix` a few months ago. The conclusion was that, since I use just a "rectangular table of values" that isn't used for matrix multiplication, I shouldn't use `Matrix` here.

> The conclusion was that, since I use just a "rectangular table of values" that isn't used for matrix multiplication, I shouldn't use `Matrix` here.

This is also why I have `Function.swap` rather than `Matrix.transpose` here.
Ok, then ignore that part of my review.

Thanks!

bors r+

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8055736752/job/22003251088)

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8056744812/job/22006455636)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8056768926/job/22006538842)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8056768926/job/22006538527)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8056768926/job/22006538979)

The fact that you have 10 definitions without lemmas and then 1 result with a ~100 line proof suggests that you're not properly developing API for your earlier definitions. Is there nothing you can prove about the earlier definitions that shortens the proof? Are there no parts of the proof that would be natural as lemmas?

One global comment. The docstring for the `![...]` notation explicitly states
> Note that this should not be used as syntax for `Matrix` as it generates a term with the wrong type.
The `!![a, b; c, d]` syntax (provided by `Matrix.matrixNotation`) should be used instead.

Similarly, `Function.AdmitsFractional` should probably quantify over `Matrix (Fin n) (Fin m) D`.

Note: you need to import `Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Notation` to do this

This looks like nonsense to me, you probably want
```suggestion
def FractionalOperation (D : Type*) (m k : ℕ) : Type _ :=
```
or if you want to be explicit
```suggestion
def FractionalOperation (D : Type u) (m k : ℕ) : Type u :=
```
Thanks!
Are these intended to be matrices?
Yes. Should I use the version that explicitly talks about matrices?

I mean, they are several "vectors". I don't really perform typical linear-algebraic matrix manipulations with them. Nevertheless, the operation `.tt` can be expressed in the language of matrix transpositions plus extra steps (see the comment above this definition).
Use the matrix notation: `!![a,b;c,d]` (maybe with comma and semicolon swapped).
Should I also use `Matrix` as type?

You should use `!!` notation if and only if you are using `Matrix` as a type. Whether you use `Matrix` will depend on whether mathematically you want to think of these as matrices, or tuples of tuples.

I want to think of them as tuples of tuples, but imagining it as a matrix is also possible.

I guess, if I don't do matrix multiplication, treating it as `Matrix` would be superfluous, right?
If you genuinely would never multiply them (or dot product with a vector), then I agree that `Matrix` is probably a bad idea.

```suggestion
    m • ((List.finRange k).map <| f ∘ ω.tt x).sum ≤
    k • ((List.finRange m).map <| f ∘ x).sum
```
Why not just write this as the definition below? (modulo my dot notation suggestions). We're talking about saving a handful of characters in the code at the expense of hundreds in a comment.

Since you're not working with matrices, this is defeq abuse; why not just
```suggestion
  swap (fun (i : Fin n) => ω (swap x i))
```

A minor change to match your comment above
```suggestion
    m • ((List.finRange k).map fun i => f (ω.tt x i)).sum ≤
    k • ((List.finRange m).map fun i => f (x i)).sum
```

```suggestion
    (ω : FractionalOperation D m k) (x : Fin m → Fin n → D) :
    Fin k → Fin n → D :=
```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [univ_val_map_2x2, ← mcfab.left, Multiset.sum_ofList_twice] at contr ```
Indeed. Seems like a job for `fin_cases`?
If this is to be kept, move to a `Multiset` file

On the topic of breaking up this lemma maybe this `have` statement can be refactored? Something like
```
lemma rows_lt {C' : Type*} [OrderedCancelAddCommMonoid C']
    {f : (Fin 2 → D) → C'} (a b : D) (mcf : f.HasMaxCutPropertyAt a b)
    {ω : FractionalOperation D 2} (valid : ω.IsValid) (symmega : ω.IsSymmetric) : ∀ r ∈ (ω.tt ![![a, b], ![b, a]]), f ![a, b] < f r := by
  sorry
```

The only other thing I am noticing is that is unconventional to have numerals in theorem names. So perhaps these could be changed and perhaps moved to a matrix related file. Other than that, I have no more comments.
Would you name it `column_of_two_mul_two_left` then? Wouldn't it hint more towards operations on integers (`2*2=4`) then to sizes of matrices?

I wouldn't use mul. I might call it `Matrix.fin_two_column_zero` or something like that.

But another alternative is just to ditch these lemmas and close the goal with
`convert symmega ![a, b] ![b, a] (List.Perm.swap b a []) o in_omega using 2 <;> ext i <;> fin_cases i <;> rfl`
See for example the file https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Matrix/Notation.html#Matrix.one_fin_two
Thanks! I'll rename them.
I renamed and moved them. You can check it now.

`simp` can almost prove these lemmas by itself. It's only missing 
```
@[simp]
lemma const_fin1_eq {α : Type*} (x : α) : (fun _ : Fin 1 ↦ x) = ![x] := 
  Matrix.cons_fin_one x _ |>.symm
```
Though I'm not sure if that is a good global simp-lemma. 

In any case, you can replace the line `rw [column_of_2x2_left, column_of_2x2_right]` by `simp [← Matrix.cons_fin_one]` and then you don't need any extra lemma.
Did you see this comment?
Yes, I did. It doesn't seem like improvement.
using `simp` seems better than an unbounded number of required lemmas of the form `fin_n_column_m`.
OK, I tried your suggestion. However `simp [← Matrix.cons_fin_one]` does not work.

You can replace
```
  rw [Matrix.fin_two_column_zero, Matrix.fin_two_column_one]
  exact symmega ![a, b] ![b, a] (List.Perm.swap b a []) o in_omega
```
by
```
  convert symmega ![a, b] ![b, a] (List.Perm.swap b a []) o in_omega using 2 <;>
    ext j <;> fin_cases j <;> rfl
```
but it is a bit obfuscated.

I prefer to have a lemma for such a thing.
What about `private lemma` in my file?

Ah, my bad about `simp [← Matrix.cons_fin_one]` not working. `simp [const_fin1_eq]` should work, and I think that should become a global simp lemma (though that transition might break things elsewhere, so that might not be great solution).
Doing that would have my strong preference, since it is one lemma that does it for all `n x m` matrices, instead of requiring many lemmas for all sizes.
I get "simp made no progress".
`import Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Notation`
All right! Let's see whether the whole Mathlib builds now.
It doesn't. I'll try to fix it once I return to my office.
Assuming you still want to have it as a global simp lemma.
It depends on how bad the failures are. Feel free to make it a non-simp lemma, and use `simp [const_fin1_eq]` in your case.
OK, I'll have a look once I build Mathlib locally.
You know you can get the Mathlib cache also for branches, right? (So you don't have to build locally.)

My impression is that it doesn't work on my computer. For example `Mathlib.Analysis.Analytic.Inverse` failed in the CI, which means all of dependencies should be built correctly on the server, right? Yet if I `lake exe cache get` and then open this file in VS Code, its building takes forever.
All right, it seems I fixed all the errors caused by adding the new simp lemma. Is there anything else you want me to change?
Oh, there is something wrong in the `test` folder now.
I left a TODO in `test/matrix`. I don't want to fix the test if I don't know what the purpose of the test is.

This new simp lemmas is breaking things we don't want to break. `simp` should still work on the proofs where it worked before. 
We can do that by adding more simp lemmas (e.g. `![a] + ![b] = ![a + b]` and for many other operations than `+`). Ideally sufficiently many so that all the existing proofs work without modification (i.e. not removing this lemma from the simp-set). This is my preferred solution, but more work.
But feel free to also remove the simp-attribute simp-lemma globally (potentially with a comment `Floris thinks we should make this a global simp lemma, but that requires a bunch of extra simp-lemmas to not break existing simp reductions`).
All right, I will add "singleton lemmas" for `+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, what else? Smul?
I removed the `@[simp]` tag on `const_fin1_eq`. Let's review this PR as it is. After merging, I'll create another PR that adds the `@[simp]` tag and solves all the related side quests.
Seeing as how this already exists, this should be deleted
Unfortunately, it cannot be plugged into my proof directly. I need a different (yet defeq) variant.

You could use 
`  simp only [Fin.sum_univ_two, Matrix.cons_val_zero, Matrix.cons_val_one, Matrix.head_cons, ← mcfab.left, ← two_nsmul] at contr`
Thanks for the suggestion! I nevertheless want to have it as a lemma. This should be an atomic step for the "big" proof.

How about using 
```
  rw [Fin.sum_univ_two] at contr
  dsimp at contr
  rw [← mcfab.left, ← two_nsmul] at contr
```
in the proof below?

Alternatively, you can generalize this to `Finset.univ.sum (fun i => f (![x, y] i)) = f x + f y` and move directly under `Fin.sum_univ_two`.
I didn't see the last two comments yet. Feel free to pursue my "Alternatively".
I don't want to make the most complicated proof more complicated than it already is. I will keep it as a separate lemma. Feel free to suggest a different name for the lemma.

> Alternatively, you can generalize this to Finset.univ.sum (fun i => f (![x, y] i)) = f x + f y and move directly under Fin.sum_univ_two.

I would have to provide a version for products, right?
All right, I added the generalized version as you suggested.
The point of these tests was that `simp` could prove it without any help
Thanks for pointing out! It will be fixed.

And what is the point of these (now broken) tests?

```
example {α : Type _} [CommRing α] {a b c d : α} :
    Matrix.det !![a, b; c, d] = a * d - b * c := by
  simp? [Matrix.det_succ_row_zero, Fin.sum_univ_succ] says
    simp only [det_succ_row_zero, of_apply, cons_val', empty_val',
      cons_val_fin_one, cons_val_zero, det_unique, Fin.default_eq_zero, submatrix_apply,
      Fin.succ_zero_eq_one, cons_val_one, head_fin_const, Fin.sum_univ_succ, Fin.val_zero, pow_zero,
      one_mul, Fin.zero_succAbove, head_cons, Finset.univ_unique, Fin.val_succ, Fin.coe_fin_one,
      zero_add, pow_one, cons_val_succ, neg_mul, Fin.succ_succAbove_zero, Finset.sum_const,
      Finset.card_singleton, smul_neg, one_smul]
  ring
example {α : Type _} [CommRing α] {a b c d e f g h i : α} :
    Matrix.det !![a, b, c; d, e, f; g, h, i] =
      a * e * i - a * f * h - b * d * i + b * f * g + c * d * h - c * e * g := by
  simp? [Matrix.det_succ_row_zero, Fin.sum_univ_succ] says
    simp only [det_succ_row_zero, of_apply, cons_val', empty_val',
      cons_val_fin_one, cons_val_zero, submatrix_apply, Fin.succ_zero_eq_one, cons_val_one,
      head_cons, submatrix_submatrix, det_unique, Fin.default_eq_zero, Function.comp_apply,
      Fin.succ_one_eq_two, cons_val_two, tail_cons, head_fin_const, Fin.sum_univ_succ, Fin.val_zero,
      pow_zero, one_mul, Fin.zero_succAbove, Finset.univ_unique, Fin.val_succ, Fin.coe_fin_one,
      zero_add, pow_one, neg_mul, Fin.succ_succAbove_zero, Finset.sum_neg_distrib,
      Finset.sum_singleton, cons_val_succ, Fin.succ_succAbove_one, Nat.reduceAdd, even_two,
      Even.neg_pow, one_pow, Finset.sum_const, Finset.card_singleton, one_smul]
  ring
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: fractional polymorphisms for VCSP
